articles.title: Covid-19 vaccines in pregnancy not linked to miscarriage or stillbirth
articles.description: The risks of catching covid-19, or being vaccinated against it, during pregnancy have been debated throughout the pandemic, with research now overwhelmingly supporting that pregnant people get vaccinated
articles.content:
By Jason Arunn Murugesu
A pregnant person receives the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine against covid-19 in Schwenksville, Pennsylvania, in February 2021
HANNAH BEIER/Reuters/Alamy
The most commonly used c… [+4560 chars]

articles.title: US CO2 shortage worsened by contaminated gas from an extinct volcano
articles.description: An extinct volcano’s underground reservoir in Mississippi has supplied CO2 to US beverage makers and food processing companies for decades. But natural contamination has exacerbated an ongoing CO2 shortage
articles.content:
By Jeremy Hsu
A CO2 shortage in the US is hampering fizzy drink production
Reuters/Phil Noble
The US is experiencing a carbon dioxide shortage, which has now been intensified by natural contaminan… [+387 chars]

articles.title: Ignition confirmed in a nuclear fusion experiment for the first time
articles.description: A 2021 experiment achieved the landmark milestone of nuclear fusion ignition, which data analysis has now confirmed – but attempts to recreate it over the last year haven’t been able to reach ignition again
articles.content:
By Karmela Padavic-Callaghan
The National Ignition Facility at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory
We have ignition. An experiment at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratorys National Ignitio… [+406 chars]

articles.title: Losing parts of our voice box may have helped humans evolve to speak
articles.description: Unlike people, 43 species of monkeys and apes are known to have so-called vocal membranes, which may prevent them from having precise voice control
articles.content:
By Clare Wilson
Unlike in other primates, the human voice box has lost small tissue structures called vocal membranes, which may have been involved in the evolution of speech
SEBASTIAN KAULITZKI/SC… [+2821 chars]

articles.title: Hovering robots could get more lift by 'treading water' in the air
articles.description: Moving like an insect may not be the most efficient way for tiny flying robots to hover – they get more lift by taking advantage of whirlpools of air that form under their wings
articles.content:
By Karmela Padavic-Callaghan
Robots with wings designed to mimic insects may hover better by using them in a unnatural way
PjrStudio/Alamy
Small robots could get more lift when they hover if they … [+365 chars]

articles.title: Cornea made from pig collagen gives people who were blind 20/20 vision
articles.description: Twenty people who were legally blind or visually impaired received a transplant of a cornea made from pig collagen. All of them had improved sight including three who now have 20/20 vision after being legally blind
articles.content:
By Corryn Wetzel
The cornea made from pig collagen
THOR BALKHED/LINKÖPING UNIVERSITY
Corneas made from pig collagen have restored sight for people who were previously legally blind or visually imp… [+2624 chars]

articles.title: T. rex’s unusual eye sockets helped it evolve a powerful bite
articles.description: Some large, meat-eating dinosaurs such as Tyrannosaurus rex had keyhole-shaped eye sockets, and reconstructions suggest this helped them bite with greater force
articles.content:
By Riley Black
Tyrannosaurus rex with its original eye socket and eye (left) and a hypothetical reconstruction with a circular eye socket and enlarged eye (right)
Stephan Lautenschlager, University… [+2280 chars]

articles.title: Why thinking hard for several hours can leave you mentally exhausted
articles.description: Prolonged concentration may cause a compound called glutamate - which can be harmful at high levels - to accumulate in regions at the front of the brain
articles.content:
By Clare Wilson
Prolonged concentration may cause a compound called glutamate to accumulate in the brain, leading to mental fatigue
Dmitriy Shironosov/Alamy

articles.title: How can England secure its water supply as droughts get more frequent?
articles.description: A growing population and climate change means the UK needs to consider long-term measures like major reservoirs and water transfers, not just short-term fixes like hosepipe bans
articles.content:
By Adam Vaughan
England’s driest July since 1935 has left the grass parched in Greenwich Park, London

articles.title: Millimetre-wave beams could give us access to deep geothermal energy
articles.description: Optimised for fusion research, millimetre-wave beam technology could be adapted to access the heat that lies several kilometres below Earth's surface, says Eugene Linden
articles.content:
